abstract: South Carolina is poised to officially vacate 1961 misdemeanor conviction against the Friendship 9, black civil rights protesters who were arrested at segregated lunch counter in Rock Hill, convicted of trespassing and sentenced to 30 days in jail; their refusal to pay fines and instead serve jail terms was seen as courageous by activists at time, who became inspired to fight against segregation of restaurants and other public facilities in South.
lead_paragraph: In a courtroom on Wednesday morning, the State of South Carolina is expected to officially vacate the life-changing misdemeanor conviction that it secured more than a half-century ago against participants in a sit-in.
snippet: In a courtroom on Wednesday morning, the State of South Carolina is expected to officially vacate the life-changing misdemeanor conviction that it secured more than a half-century ago against participants in a sit-in.

headline.main: Decades After Sit-In, South Carolina Seeks to Make Things Right
headline.print_headline: More Than 50 Years On, Trying to Make It Right
